text:
I posted this in <#CJ5DN6RKP|email-development> previously, so apologies for the cross-post. Just hoping a wider audience might be able to lend some insight?

We're working on a campaign where we need a single link within an email to appear as a different domain when the user hovers on it (or copy/pastes it from the email).

e.g.
• Link 1: <http://www.example.com/link1|www.example.com/link1>
• Link2: <http://www.anotherdomain.com/link2|www.anotherdomain.com/link2>

It's not desirable for us to deactivate the 'track click' options the settings for this particular portal.

Any ideas how we could make this happen?

We have our website self-hosted and are using the HubSpot tracking code. We control cookies ourselves to load both HubSpot tracking code and Google Analytics tracking code. Can I integrate Google Analytics into HubSpot so that both cookies are controlled by HubSpot and use the HubSpot GDPR banner? I think the Google Analytics integration requires me to connect my domain to HubSpot, but I understand that this does not work with self-hosted websites. In this case it would not be possible to integrate GA into HubSpot to control cookies from within HubSpot. Am I right?
is it possible to limit the number of displayed tags in a blog?
<@UBT0AHWLD> are you referring to on the front / viewers end? or in the editor?
front viewer
the visitor of the page
the editor likes to pick a lot tags which does not look good
hang on. I'll give you a snippet

<@UBT0AHWLD>
``` {% if content.topic_list %}
             <p id="HubSpot-topic_data" > Topics:
                {% for topic in content.topic_list|sort(False, False,'name') %}
               {% if loop.index <= "3" %}
                    <a class="topic-link" href="{{ group.absolute_url }}/topic/{{ topic.slug }}">{{ topic.name }}</a>{% if loop.index != "3" %},{% endif %}
               {% endif %}
                {% endfor %}
             </p>
        {% endif %}```
great, thank you so much!

page speed insights still shows a TON of module css files not concatenating.
With enough clients worried about a google page speed score, it is starting to make me rethink using custom modules to house css. There are no errors in the css reported by HubSpot, but they are still not combining into one file. Is there anything I could be doing wrong?
create a redirect or a tracking url
does HubSpot control google analytics cookie?
are you verifying that they aren't? I don't believe that HubSpot concats css files when a user agent of a bot is there
GA doesn't collect any user data, so turning off your GA doesn't seem to be necessary

Hey folks, got a simple one hopefully. I need to add a date property token to an email that'll go out to both UK&US markets. UK will expect to see the token & date format as dd/mm/yyyy, where the US mm/dd/yyyy. How do I correctly display this date token format for contacts?

Note: Recipient lists separate the 2 markets out and marketing teams create separate emails for each
with the way hubl works in emails, it might be easier to clone the template and change the date format on one, and send them out individually
<@U3T21PDBK> Another thing that happens is that is there is any animation it wont concatenate either.
cause it shows things in different positions
I am verifying in the sources tab <@U25PYL3Q8>
Animations in any file breaks the whole thing? <@U38EZFVFE> ?
I'm guessing it is @keyframe related ?
might be able to clone page, remove that module that has keyframes and test
Generally I run my css through a validator
then remove the modules until I get it to concat
or add them until it breaks
You could likely place that information in a rich text and use smart content based on location.
Thats probably a better solution
not nessesarily. but i know WOW does a number on it sometimes
or animate.css
honestly tho. i have more issues than normal getting thing sto minify and concant
Is there a way that we can get errors displayed from concat if we do hsDebug??
hmm, I think that prevents min and concat so maybe not
with the amount of times the has bitten me in the rear, I might just gulp it

GA does collect user data (IP related stuff like geolocation and such, which falls under gdpr). I think you can configure GA to only collect anonymous data but its not straightforward, so for the momento we are pulling the plug on GA when there's no consent.
HMm, I was thinking that GA auto switched over to anonymous data when that happened, I'll have to go back and look back into that. I think I made a crappy assumption!
I'm not sure how that works with HubSpot and if you have GA connected, if it prevents that from happening, hopefully someone at HubSpot can chime in here today
<@U7SL518D6> this seems like a topic for the super team!

:speaking_head_in_silhouette: In case you missed it, last week released an open source app built on the HubSpot CMS: <https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-event-registration>. It’s a really great example of how you can connect the CMS, local development, serverless functions, memberships and HubDB to add a bunch of functionality to a site. Check out the project and if you have any questions/feedback :point_right: <#C011GFF8KNZ|events-app-beta>
i spent 6  hours debugging css for this one day recently
I think I spent a good 30 minutes on that one as well if that is the same one
this was for another company
great example of not concanting view-source:<https://www.modusadvanced.com/resources/blog/of-course-there-is-value-working-with-lord>
no css errors

I've been wanting to experiment with minifying module CSS locally and using it in a {% require_css %} <style> block in the header to compare performance. Would also ideally bundle all modules together in a master "modules.css" file that could then be async deferred so it could be cached.
i do think that if there is a lot of inline css in the dom it does take longer for the server to render the page.
i notice that when the ttfb is longer
can be for sure, I've just seen some platforms take that approach of at least having above the fold CSS inlined in the head, just curious about how it would work on HS
